byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, SARAH COHEN and ERIC LICHTBLAU

abstract: Most of the 2016 presidential hopefuls have been spending money for months on their campaign efforts, but accounting procedures have permitted them to disavow that spending as campaign-related in order to save donated cash for later use in primaries; campaigns defend practice but some election lawyers argue campaigns are testing or crossing legal boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Though most of the presidential candidates have been testing early primary states for months, the costs were not counted as campaign money until just recently, raising accounting and regulatory questions.

headline.main: Presidential Race Just Started? Not According to the Spending
headline.print_headline: Presidential Race Just Started? Not According to the Spending

snippet: Though most of the presidential candidates have been testing early primary states for months, the costs were not counted as campaign money until just recently, raising accounting and regulatory questions.
